metadata.title: Facile synthesis and characterization of TiO2–graphene–ZnFe2-xTbxO4 ternary nano-hybrids

sections.text:
Received: 21 December 2016
Accepted: 17 February 2017
Springer Science+Business Media New York 2017
Rare earth ion (Tb3?)-doped zinc ferrite (ZnFe2O4) nanoparticles grown on reduced graphene oxide (RGO) prepared through sol–gel method have been reported. During the sol–gel process, graphene oxide was reduced to RGO, and, subsequently, anatase TiO2 and cubic spinel ZnFe2-xTbxO4 were grown in situ on the surfaces of the RGO nano-sheets. The structure, surface morphology and chemical composition of ternary nano-composites were studied using scanning electron microscopy, energy-dispersive X-ray, X-ray diffraction (XRD), Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy, photoluminescence spectra and vibrating sample magnetometer (VSM). XRD results showed that the produced TiO2 was composed of anatase and some rutile phases and ZnFe2O4 with a cubic spinel structure. The particle sizes of ZnFe2O4 and TiO2 nanoparticles were in the ranges of *65–80 and *17–20 nm, respectively. The saturation magnetization (MS) determined from VSM was found to linearly increase with Tb 3? concentration.

sections.heading: Introduction
sections.text:
Graphene (GR) has been one of the most significant nano-materials in the field of nanotechnology research for the past years. Graphene is a two-dimensional single atomic layer of sp2-bonded carbon atoms, densely packed into a honeycomb crystal lattice [1–3]. Graphene has a zero energy band gap,
which depends on the position of the Fermi level. It has large theoretical specific surface areas of up to [2600 m2/g, high surface-to-volume ratios, high electrocatalytic activities, robust mechanical properties, an extremely high thermal conductivity (5000 Wm-1 K-1) [4–6]. These fascinating properties make graphene suitable for many potential technological applications such as nano-electronics,
Address correspondence to E-mail: kpmrahimi@ihu.ac.ir; rahiminasrabadi@gmail.com
DOI 10.1007/s10853-017-0934-8
photocatalyst, sensors, solar cells, supercapacitors, nano-composite applications, hydrogen storage devices and energy storage and conversion [7, 8]. Graphene-based nano-hybrids containing metal nanoparticles (Cu, Pt, Pd, Au, Ag), metal oxides (TiO2, ZnFe2O4, CoFe2O4, NiFe2O4, CuFe2O4, Fe3O4, SnO2, MnO2, Co3O4, ZnO) and polymers have been discussed in various reports [9–11]. Graphene–titania–zinc ferrite ternary nano-hybrids have been studied in the recent years for various applications such as hydrogen evolution through hydrolysis and photocatalytic degradation of various dyes [12, 13]. The common synthesis routes for preparing a TiO2– GR–ZnFe2-xTbxO4 ternary nano-composite include sol–gel, UV-assisted, gas/liquid interface reaction, in situ chemical synthesis, or oxidation, laser irradiation, sono-chemical and ultra-sonication, microwave methods, or solvothermal or hydrothermal approaches [14–16].
Currently, various semiconductors are under evaluation. These primarily include TiO2, ZnO, SrMoO4, MnO2, Fe2O3, NiO, ZrO2, Cu2O, CuS, ZnS, CuWO4, CoWO4, CdS, CdSe, Ag3PO4, and mixtures thereof. Titanium dioxide (TiO2 spherical nanometer powders) is one of the most widely studied semiconducting metal oxides, which has attracted a great deal of interest due to its unique properties [17–22]. Under UV illumination, electrons are excited from the valence band of a semiconductor (TiO2) to its conduction band, forming electron–hole (e-–h?) pairs that are mainly responsible for the photocatalytic activity of the compounds [23]. Notably, spherical TiO2 nano-structures still suffer several drawbacks, such as a wide intrinsic band gap (Eg = 3.2 eV for anatase TiO2) which allows the spherical TiO2 nano-sized to respond to light only at the narrow wavelength range of ultraviolet radiation less than 387 nm (only about 3–5% of total sunlight), fast recombination of (e-–h?) pairs and a limited photoresponding range, which to a great extent, hinders their photoelectrochemical activities as well as applications [24]. So far, various strategies have been explored for fabricating high-performance nano-crystalline TiO2. These include simple mixture/sonication, hydrothermal, solvothermal and sol–gel processes [25–27]. The sol–gel synthesis of ceramic oxides offers advantages such as the purity of the product, good homogeneity of the solution, control over the concentration, nucleation and growth of colloidal particles (shape, size and size
distribution), requiring simple instrumentation, and low processing temperatures [28]. One way to synthesize spherical TiO2 nano-sized powders is the sol– gel technique. This wet-chemical process is able to produce multiple forms of materials including monosized nanoparticles, porous nano-crystals, two and ternary nano-hybrid, thin films, nano-rods, nanotubes and nano-fibers [29].
Recently, various iron-based oxides, i.e., MFe2O4, have been investigated in various applications such as anode materials, sensors, electronics, solar cells, photocatalysis and catalysts [30, 31]. Zinc ferrite (ZnFe2O4) seems to be a potential candidate semiconductor available for coupling with TiO2 nanocrystals and has attracted much interest due to its specific electronic structure, which is reflected by its applications in areas like electronic devices and magnetic resonance imaging [32, 33]. On the other hand, spinal zinc ferrite (ZnFe2O4) which has a narrow band gap (1.9 eV) exhibits a wide range of functional properties for practical applications, such as interesting magnetic behavior, response to visible light and good photochemical stability [33]. Zinc ferrite nanoparticles have also been synthesized through different physical and chemical methods such as hydrothermal, solvothermal, sol–gel and coprecipitation procedures. The main phases present in TiO2 and ZnFe2O4 nanoparticles are the anatase phase and cubic spinel structure, respectively [34, 35].
In the present study, the synthesis of TiO2–graphene–ZnFe2-xTbxO4 nanoparticles through a simple sol–gel method without the need for vacuum or high pressure conditions has been evaluated.

sections.heading: Materials
sections.text:
Zn(NO3)2 6H2O (Mw = 290.70 g/mol), FeCl3 6H2O (Mw = 270.43 g/mol), Tb(NO3)3 6H2O (Mw = 173 g/mol), TiCl4 (Mw = 189.679 g/mol), ethanol, citric acid monohydrate (chemical structure: C6H8O7 H2O, Mw = 208 g/mol), sodium dodecyl sulfate (SDS (chemical structure: NaC12H25SO4, Mw = 288.372 g/mol) and cetyl-trimethyl-ammonium bromide) (CTAB), (chemical structure: C19H42BrN, Mw = 364.45 g/mol) were purchased from Merck Co. and used without further purification. Deionized water was prepared using an ultrapure water system
(Smart-2-Pure, TKACo, Germany). The specifications of the graphene sample used include: thickness: 50–100 nm, diameter: 5 lm, purity: 96–99%, oxygen content: 1% and BET surface area: 13 m2/g. The graphene samples used in the tests were purchased from Angstron Materials XG Sciences.
Synthesis of the anatase TiO2 nano-crystals
Anatase TiO2 nano-crystals were prepared by a wet process (sol–gel technique). In general, TiCl4 (10 mmol) was added to a mixture of 10 mL of doubly distilled water (DI) and 10 mL of ethanol under vigorous stirring at room temperature until a stable and homogenous solution was formed. Next citric acid monohydrate and SDS solutions were added to this solution while keeping the molar ratio of SDS to citric acid at 1:2. The solution was kept for 3 h on a plated magnetic stirrer until it became homogeneous. The prepared solution was kept in a dark place for the nucleation process to establish for 24 h. Next the mixture was gelated in an oven at 70 C for 12 h and the resulting gel was dried at 110 C and subsequently, the resulting material was powdered and then sintered in a muffle furnace at 500 C for 2 h in air atmosphere.

sections.heading: Synthesis of 10 wt% TiO2–5 wt% RGO–
sections.text:
ZnFe22xTbxO4 ternary nano-composites and pure ZnFe2O4 nanoparticles
The sol–gel procedure was based on the formation of a stable and homogenous solution prepared by mixing appropriate amount of FeCl3 6H2O (4.0 mmol),
Zn(NO3)2 6H2O (2.0 mmol), and Tb(NO3)3 6H2O (0.01 till 0.09 mol%) in a 1:1 ethanol/ DI mixture under magnetic stirring for 3 h to form a homogeneous solution. Then a suspension of 5 wt% of RGO and 10 wt% of TiO2 (prepared in mixture of 10 mL of DI and 20 mL of ethanol) was added to this solution at room temperature under magnetic stirring. The citric acid monohydrate solution and CTAB (1:2) were next added to this solution under magnetic stirring. The solution was kept on a plated magnetic stirrer for 180 min until it became homogeneous, and then it was dried at 145 C over night (Fig. 1). The obtained ternary nano-composite of 10 wt% TiO2– 5 wt% RGO–ZnFe2-xTbxO4 was calcinated in a muffle furnace at 600 C for 30 min. For the sake of
comparison, the same method was used for the synthesize of pure ZnFe2O4 without GO, TiO2 and Tb(NO3)3.6H2O.

sections.heading: Characterization of the nanoparticles and nano-composites
sections.text: Phases analyses of the prepared samples were carried out by powder XRD (Philips X’ pert Pro MPD, Holland) using graphite-filtered Cu Ka (k = 0.154 nm) radiation in a 2h range from 10 to 90 with a step size of 0.021 and a measuring time of 0.8 s per point. The morphology of the samples was studied by SEM (Tescan MIRA3 FEG- SEM, Czech) equipped with an EDX (Tescan MIRA3 FEG- EDAX, Czech) at 30 kV. The samples were dispersed onto a carbon tape. TiO2 samples were sputter coated with gold prior to analysis. FT-IR spectra of the samples were recorded on a FT-IR spectrophotometer (Nicolet Magna IR 550 spectrometer, USA). The magnetic measurements were taken at room temperature using a PMC MicroMag 3900 model vibrating sample magnetometer (VSM) with a 1-Tesla magnet (Meghnatis Daghigh Kavir Co.; Kashan, Iran). The photoluminescence (PL) properties were studied using Varian Cary Eclipse fluorescence spectrophotometer.

sections.heading: XRD analyses
sections.text:
Figure 2 shows the X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of pure TiO2 and ZnFe2O4 nanoparticles and 10 wt% TiO2–5 wt% RGO–ZnFe2-xTbxO4 ternary nano-hybrid (x = 0.01, 0.03, 0.05, 0.07 and 0.09 mol% Tb3?) calcinated at 600 C (150 min), respectively. XRD is commonly used for the identification of the crystal phase and structure as well as the crystallite size of all phases present in the sample. The peaks at 2h values of 18.3 , 30.1 , 35.3 , 43.0 , 53.5 , 56.3 , 62.4 , 70.6 and 74.5 can be indexed to (111), (220), (311),
(400), (422), (511), (440), (533) and (622) crystal planes of cubic spinel ZnFe2O4, respectively, (space group Fd-3m, JCPDS No. 74-2397) with the calculated cell parameter of a = b = c 8.4432 Å. The peaks at 2h values of 33 , 41 , 50 confirmed the formation of Fe2O3 (JCPDS No. 02-1047). The peaks at 2h values of 25.3, 37.8, 48.0, 53.9, 55.1, 62.7, 68.8, 70.3 and 75.0 can be indexed to (101), (004), (200), (105), (211), (204), (116), (220) and (215) crystal planes of anatase TiO2, respectively. This can be held as proof that rutile and brookite phases were not present in the sample. There were special diffraction peaks in 10 wt% TiO2– 5 wt% RGO–ZnFe2-xTbxO4 ternary nano-hybrid (x = 0.01, 0.03, 0.05, 0.07, 0.09) at 2h values of 25.3 , 48 and 55.1 , which may be assigned to the reflections of (101), (200) and (211) planes of pure anatase TiO2 (JCPDS Card No. 21-1217), respectively. The XRD pattern of the as-prepared 10 wt% TiO2–5 wt% RGO–ZnFe2-xTbxO4 ternary nano-hybrid showed an additional weak peak around at 2h = 26.5 , which was attributed to the (002) plane of the hexagonal graphite structure (JCPDS card No. 41-1487), suggesting that graphene is present in the TiO2 and ZnFe2O4 ternary nano-composites [36, 37]. However, no special diffraction peaks corresponding to the separate Tb2O3 were observed in the case of 10 wt% TiO2–5 wt% RGO–ZnFe2-xTbxO4 ternary nano-composite patterns. The Debye–Scherrer equation:
D ¼ kk b cos h
ð1Þ
was used for calculating the average crystallite size of the samples. In this equation, k is a constant which equals 0.9, k is the wavelength of the X-ray radiation (k = 0.154056 nm), b is the corrected band broadening [(FWHM) full-width at half-maximum] after subtraction the equipment broadening, and h is the Bragg angle [38]. The average crystallite sizes calculated for the ZnFe2O4 NPs, Tb-doped ZnFe2O4 NPs and pure TiO2 using the Debye–Scherrer equation were in the ranges of *30–45, *30–45 and *10–13 nm, respectively.
Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and EDX analysis
Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) was used to characterize the morphology of the samples. The SEM images of pure TiO2 and ZnFe2O4 nanoparticles are illustrated in Fig. 3a, b, and those of the 10 wt%
bFigure 3 SEM images of a pure TiO2; b ZnFe2O4 NPs; c 10 wt%
TiO2–5 wt% RGO–ZnFe2-xTbxO4 nano-hybrid (x = 0.01 mol% Tb3?); d 10 wt% TiO2–5 wt% RGO–ZnFe2-xTbxO4 nano-hybrid (x = 0.09 mol% Tb3?); e EDX for the pure TiO2 NPs; f EDX for the 10 wt% TiO2–5 wt% RGO–ZnFe2-xTbxO4 nano-hybrid (x = 0.01 mol% Tb3?) calcinated at 600 C.
TiO2–5 wt% RGO–ZnFe2-xTbxO4 ternary nano-hybrid (x = 0.01 mol% Tb3? and x = 0.09 mol% Tb3?) are shown in Fig. 3c, d, respectively. The SEM images of TiO2 and ZnFe2O4 indicated the homogeneous distribution of the spherical or oval TiO2 and cubic spinel zinc ferrite (ZnFe2O4) that rarely agglomerated. As it can be seen in Fig. 3c, d, the graphene nano-sheets were fully exfoliated and uniformly decorated with pure TiO2 and ZnFe2-xTbxO4
nanoparticles. Figure 3a, b indicates that the average diameters of ZnFe2O4 and TiO2 nanoparticles were in the range of about *65–80 and *17–20 nm, respectively.
Energy-dispersive X-ray (EDX) analysis was used to investigate the chemical composition of the synthesized TiO2 nanoparticles (Fig. 3e), and 10 wt% TiO2–5 wt% RGO–ZnFe2-xTbxO4 ternary nano-hybrid (x = 0.01 mol% Tb3?; Fig. 3f). The EDX analyses indicated the presence of Zn, Fe, Ti, C and O, further demonstrating the successful formation of nanocomposite.

sections.heading: FT-IR spectroscopy analyses
sections.text:
Figure 4 shows a Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectrum of the pure TiO2 nanoparticles and 10 wt% TiO2–5 wt% RGO–ZnFe2-xTbxO4 ternary nano-composites (x = 0.01, 0.03, 0.05, 0.07 and 0.09 mol%). For the 10 wt% TiO2–5 wt% RGO–ZnFe2-xTbxO4, the adsorption peak around 1570 cm-1 can be assigned to the stretching vibrations of the un-oxidized carbon backbone, and the two strong absorption peaks at lower frequencies
Sample MS (emu/g) Mr (emu/g) HC (kQe)
Yellow 2.60 0.264 66 Pink 2 0.332 80 Blue 1.75 0.211 77.50 Black 1.6 0.159 68 Green 1.50 0.167 68
(around 550 and 415 cm-1) can be assigned to the stretching vibrations of the Zn–O bonds in the tetrahedral positions and the Fe–O bonds in octahedral positions, respectively [39–42]. The broad absorption peaks around 3400 cm-1 correspond to the surface absorbed water and the hydroxyl groups [43–45]. The graphene samples also showed several peaks centered at 1568, 2862, 2904 and 1118 cm-1, which were attributed to feature distinctive stretching and vibration modes of C–C and the stretching vibration modes of C–H, respectively.
The characteristic absorption band at around 2345 cm-1 is attributed to the C=O vibrations [46]. Further, the absorption signals in the 400–800 cm-1 range could be attributed to the stretching vibration modes of Ti–O–Ti/Ti–O–C in pure TiO2 and TiO2-based ternary nano-composites [47].

sections.heading: Analysis of the magnetic properties
sections.text: The magnetic properties of the 10 wt% TiO2–5 wt% RGO–ZnFe2-xTbxO4 ternary nano-composites of different Tb3? contents (i.e., x = 0.01, 0.03, 0.05, 0.07 and 0.09 mol% Tb3?) were measured by VSM, and the results are presented in Fig. 5. It can be clearly seen that all samples had hard magnetic properties. Also, it can be clearly understood from Table 1 and Fig. 5 that an increase in rare earth ion (Tb3?) content leads to increases in the saturation magnetization (MS) of the ternary nano-hybrid. The 10 wt% TiO2–5 wt% RGO–ZnFe2-xTbxO4 (x = 0.07 mol% Tb 3?) sample displayed the maximum remanent (Mr) and coercivity (HC) magnetization. This happens due to the fact that terbium ions (Tb3?) are expected to occupy the octahedral sites of zinc ferrites because of their large size. Coercivity, remanent and saturation magnetization values of the samples are listed in Table 1.

sections.heading: Photoluminescence (PL) spectra
sections.text:
Figure 6 demonstrates the representative photoluminescence (PL) spectra of the 10 wt% TiO2–5 wt% RGO– ZnFe2-xTbxO4 (i.e., x = 0.01, 0.03, 0.05, 0.07 and 0.09 mol% Tb3?) ternary nano-composites. The photoluminescence emission, which originates from the direct recombination of the excited electrons and holes present in the semiconductor, is often used to study the surface structure. The intensity of the PL spectrum is a direct measure of the electron–hole recombination rate, i.e., the faster the recombination occurs, the more intense the spectrum shall be. Alternatively, the lower intensities
indicated that more excited electrons were trapped and stably transferred through the interface. The inset shows the magnified PL plot of the 10 wt% TiO2–5 wt% RGO– ZnFe2-xTbxO4 ternary nano-composites with 0.01–0.09 mol% Tb3? content. It can be seen that the PL intensity decreased with increasing the mol% of Tb3? in the order of 0.05[0.01[0.03[0.07[0.09. Since a lower PL intensity is generally indicative of a lower recombination rate for the photogenerated charge carriers, i.e., electron–hole pairs [48], it can be concluded that the charge separation efficiency follows the reverse order, i.e., 0.09[0.07[0.03[0.01[0.05 mol% of Tb3?.

sections.heading: Conclusion
sections.text: A room-temperature sol - gel process was employed to synthesize TiO2, ZnFe2O4 nanoparticles and 10 wt% TiO2–5 wt% RGO–ZnFe2-xTbxO4 (x = 0.01, 0.03, 0.05, 0.07 and 0.09 mol% Tb3?) ternary nanocomposites. The effects of replacing TiO2, graphene and Tb3? ions on the photoluminescence, magnetic and structural properties of nano-composites were explored. It is notable that the 10 wt% TiO2–5 wt% RGO–ZnFe2-xTbxO4 with 0.09 mol of Tb 3? showed the lowest and those of 0.05 mol of Tb3? presented the highest intensities in the PL spectra which was consistent with the charge in the separation efficiency. The XRD patterns revealed the cubic spinel structure, anatase phase and good crystalline nature of the samples. Additionally, the study further suggests that the Tb3? ions doped in the zinc ferrite nanoparticles can increase the saturation magnetization (MS) of the ternary nano-composites. SEM images revealed that ZnFe2-xYbxO4 and pure TiO2 nanoparticles with diameters ranging from *65 to 80 and from *17 to 20 nm were uniformly anchored on the surface of the RGO nano-sheets, leading to the formation of ternary nano-hybrids.

sections.text:
